data.source_text: 나는 부덕한 몸으로 한 나라를 다스린 지 이십 년이 되었다. 옛 시대의 훌륭한 정치를 회복하고자 하나 시의적절한 조치를 모르니, 정사에 미진한 것이 있고 다스림에 부족한 것이 있지 않은가? 한두 가지 일을 들어 말하자면, 군사는 나라의 큰일인데, 중국은 농사로 군사를 기르며 병사와 말이 정예롭고 무기가 날카롭다. 우리나라는 농사와 군사가 하나이니, 비록 옛 군사가 농사에 깃들어 있다는 뜻이나, 병사와 말, 무기가 중국에 크게 미치지 못하니 어찌하면 좋겠는가? 재정도 나라의 중요한 일인데, 중국은 세금 외에 소금과 철의 이익이 많아서 해마다 수입이 넘치고 국가 재정이 여유롭다. 우리나라 경비는 오직 전세로만 충당하니, 비록 옛 바른 공급의 뜻이나 쓰임이 항상 부족함에 시달리니 어찌하면 좋겠는가? 어사는 임금의 귀와 눈이다. 중국은 여러 길에 모두 분사를 두어 잘못을 살피는데, 우리나라는 그렇지 않아서 수령이 법을 어기는 자가 많으니 어찌하면 좋겠는가? 예악은 조정의 성대한 모습이라 소홀히 할 수 없다. 중국이 외국인을 접대할 때는 잡악을 쓰는데, 우리나라는 여악을 쓰니 어찌하면 좋겠는가? 이단은 나라의 큰 근심인데 불교와 도교의 해가 더욱 심하다. 한나라와 명나라 이래로 임금들이 모두 존숭하지 않음이 없었고, 간혹 그 해를 알고 없애고자 하는 자가 있었으나 끝내 이루지 못하여 지금까지 만연하니 어째서인가? 우리나라 도교는 본래 숭상하는 자가 없었는데, 승려들을 과연 모두 없앨 수 없겠는가? 만약 없애고자 한다면 백성들을 놀라게 하지 않고 가볍게 어지럽히지 않을 방책이 어디 있는가? 그대들은 옛것에 박식하고 현재에 통달하여 정치체제를 연구한 지 오래이니, 각자 마음을 다해 대답하여 나의 현자를 구하는 뜻에 부응하라.
data.target_text: With my insufficient virtue, I have ruled a country for twenty years. While desiring to restore the prosperity of ancient times, I am unclear about proper measures for the present. Could it be that there are policies not yet implemented or governance not yet perfected? Let me speak of a few matters. Military affairs are crucial to the state. In China, they nurture soldiers through farming, resulting in strong troops and sharp weapons. In our country, soldiers and farmers are one, which follows the ancient principle of combining military with agriculture, yet our military strength falls far behind China's - how can this be acceptable? Finance is also crucial to the state. China has salt and iron monopolies besides taxation, ensuring abundant national revenue. Our country's expenses rely solely on land tax, which follows the ancient principle of proper taxation, yet we constantly suffer from shortages - how can this be acceptable? Censors are the eyes and ears of the ruler. China has regional offices everywhere to monitor wrongdoing, but we do not. Many local officials violate laws - how can this be acceptable? Ritual and music are the court's dignity and should not be treated lightly. China uses various music for entertaining foreign guests, while we use female musicians - how can this be acceptable? Heterodoxy is a great harm to the state, especially Buddhism and Taoism. Since Han and Ming dynasties, rulers have revered them. Some knew their harm and wished to eliminate them but failed. Why do they still persist? In our country, Taoism had no followers originally. Can't we completely remove Buddhist monks and nuns? If we wish to remove them, how can we do so without shocking people or causing disturbance? You officials are well-versed in ancient and modern affairs and have long studied governance principles awaiting today's questions. Please answer thoughtfully to fulfill my sincere desire to seek wisdom.

data.source_text: 나라를 다스리는 도리에는 본래 큰 원칙이 있다. 그러나 시기에 따른 일은 각각 그에 맞는 것이 있다. 우리나라는 북으로는 야인과 이어져 있고 남으로는 섬 오랑캐와 접해있어, 때때로 침입의 근심이 있으나 변방 장수들이 이를 막지 못하고 있다. 최근 남쪽 군현 연해 지역에서는 왜적이라 하기도 하고 해적이라 하기도 하는 자들이 섬들 사이에서 출몰하여 자주 소동을 일으키는데, 변방 장수들이 이를 제어하지 못한다. 어떤 이는 중신을 파견하여 상황에 따라 처리하면 저들이 소문을 듣고 저절로 물러날 것이라 하고, 어떤 이는 상벌이 분명하지 않음을 걱정할 뿐이니 장수도 있고 병사도 있으니 기律을 분명히 하고 상과 벌을 확실히 하여 독려하면 굳이 중신을 더 보내지 않아도 변방이 저절로 견고해질 것이라 하며, 어떤 이는 굳이 먼저 움직일 필요 없이 대마도주와 통교하여 그들을 복종시키면 그만이라 하는데, 어느 것이 옳은가? 만포는 서쪽 경계의 요충지로, 적이 그 경내에 들어왔을 때 변방 장수가 때에 임하여 거의 다 베어 잡았다. 어떤 이는 공로를 헤아려 상을 주어 격려해야 한다 하고, 어떤 이는 적이 반드시 원한을 품고 보복할 것이니 전투 군사를 선발하여 증원하여 대비해야 한다 하며, 어떤 이는 본진의 병력으로 충분히 막을 수 있으니 굳이 서울의 군사를 더 조발하여 소란을 일으킬 필요가 없다 하는데, 어느 것이 좋은 계책인가? 제공들은 시무에 밝으니 반드시 적을 제어하고 백성을 편안하게 할 계책이 있을 것이니, 각자 자세히 글로 써내라. 내가 직접 살펴보겠다.
data.target_text: The way of governing a country has its great principles. However, appropriate measures vary according to the times. Our country borders barbarians in the north and island dwellers in the south, with occasional raids causing concern, yet frontier commanders cannot eliminate them. Recently in the southern coastal regions, whether they be Japanese pirates or sea bandits, they emerge from among the islands, repeatedly causing damage, and frontier commanders cannot control them. Some say we should dispatch high officials to handle situations as they arise, and the raiders will naturally disperse upon hearing this. Others say the only problem is unclear rewards and punishments; with commanders and soldiers in place, we should clarify regulations, ensure reliable rewards and punishments to encourage them, then there's no need to dispatch additional officials as the borders will naturally be secure. Others suggest rather than acting first, we should communicate with the lord of Tsushima Island to make him submit. Which approach is correct? At Manpo, a strategic point on the western frontier, when invaders entered, the frontier commander defeated and captured almost all of them. Some say reward their achievements to encourage them; others say the enemy will seek revenge, so we should select additional fighting troops and increase garrison forces; yet others say the local garrison's strength is sufficient for control, with no need to deploy capital troops and cause disruption. Which strategy is best? You, as officials, understand current affairs and must have strategies to control enemies and pacify the people. Detail each of your proposals. I shall review them personally.

data.source_text: 옛사람이 말하기를 "요순의 지혜는 치우치지 않았으니, 급한 일부터 먼저 했다"고 했다. 지금 나라의 일에 말할 만한 것이 많지만, 풍속을 바꾸고 선비의 기풍을 바로잡는 일보다 더 급한 것이 없다. 학교는 교화의 근원이며 인재가 나오는 곳이다. 제자 된 자는 마땅히 여유롭게 젖어들어 효제충신의 도를 밝혀 나라에 쓰임 받기를 기다려야 한다. 그런데 지금은 학교에서 책을 끼고 다니는 것을 도리어 부끄럽게 여기고, 옆길로 빠져나가는 것을 좋은 계책으로 여겨, 학업을 폐하는 것을 높은 뜻으로 삼아 날로 비루해져 인재가 드물게 나오니 교화가 진작되지 않는 것이 이 때문이다. 어찌하면 학교 교육을 밝히고 선비의 기풍을 새롭게 할 수 있겠는가? 풍속은 나라의 원기이니 마땅히 배양해야 하는데, 지금은 귀한 이를 천하게 여기고 아랫사람이 윗사람을 능멸하며, 법령을 두려워하지 않고 청렴과 부끄러움을 돌아보지 않는 자들이 있다. 조정에서는 재상을 뽑아 보내고 또 감찰관을 두어 단속하게 하지만, 여전히 금지된 물품을 몰래 사고팔며 상인을 사칭하여 나라의 법을 어기니, 나라의 법이 엄하고 치밀하지 않은 것이 아닌데도 금지시킬 수 없으니 그 까닭이 무엇인가? 혼인의 예법도 엄한 금제가 있는데 사대부 집안에서도 따르지 않고 제도를 넘어서는 일이 많으니, 어찌하면 교화가 밝아지고 상하가 분수를 지켜 명령이 행해지고 금지가 이루어지겠는가? 여러 대부들은 시무를 강구하여 논의할 날이 있을 것이니, 각자 숨김없이 말하라.
data.target_text: The ancients said: "The wisdom of Yao and Shun was not biased toward any particular matter, but focused on urgent priorities." In state affairs today, while there is much to discuss, nothing is more urgent than reforming customs, education, and scholarly practices. Schools are the source of cultural transformation and the origin of talent. Students should immerse themselves gradually, understanding the ways of filial piety, brotherhood, loyalty, and trust, preparing themselves for service to the state. Yet nowadays, carrying books through school gates is considered shameful, and taking shortcuts is deemed clever. Thus, neglecting studies has become admirable, leading to daily decline in standards, scarcity of talent, and weakening of moral education. How can we improve education and reform scholarly practices? Public morality is the vital force of the state that should be cultivated, yet now the lowly obstruct the noble, subordinates disrespect superiors, some disregard laws and ignore shame. In the capital, despite having ministers selected to govern and inspectors to supervise, there are still those who secretly trade prohibited goods, impersonating merchants and violating national laws. Though state laws are strict and comprehensive, they cannot effectively prohibit such behavior - why is this so? Marriage customs have strict regulations, yet even scholar-official families do not observe them, with many exceeding proper limits. How can we achieve moral transformation, maintain proper order between high and low, and ensure that commands are followed and prohibitions respected? You gentlemen who study current affairs and await discussion, please speak your thoughts without reservation.

data.source_text: 장수의 재능이 국가에 관계되는 바가 크다. 지혜와 용기와 덕이 있어 각각 장점이 있으되, 이 세 가지를 겸비한 자는 실로 얻기 어렵고, 어느 한 쪽에 뛰어난 자도 버릴 수 없다. 옛날에 이 세 가지를 겸비한 자는 누구인가? 어느 한 쪽에 뛰어나 이름을 날린 자는 누구인가? 우리나라는 삼면이 적을 맞고 있어 무를 써야 하는 땅이다. 장수를 선발하고 임명하는 것이 우선되어야 하는데, 기르는 것이 미리 하지 않은 것이 아니요, 선발하는 것이 정밀하지 않은 것이 아닌데도 인재가 드물게 나오니, 혹은 용기만 있고 책략이 부족하며, 혹은 무예만 있고 문을 알지 못하여, 적을 만나면 겁을 내어 공이 적고, 일을 당하면 어두워 방도를 알지 못하니, 장수를 어찌 쓰겠는가? 어떻게 하면 기르고 선발하는 방도를 얻어 온전한 인재들이 많이 나와서 위급할 때 쓸 수 있겠는가? 이를 마음을 다해 답하라.
data.target_text: The importance of military talent to the nation is great. Speaking of wisdom, courage, and virtue, each has its strengths, and while those who possess all three are indeed hard to find, those who excel in one should not be discarded either. Who in ancient times possessed all three? Who became famous for excelling in one? Our country faces enemies on three sides and is a place where military prowess is needed. Selecting and appointing generals should be the priority, and while we neither neglect their nurturing nor compromise in selection, talented ones rarely emerge. Some are merely brave but lack strategy, others are only skilled in warfare but ignorant of literature. They become timid and achieve little when facing the enemy, and when confronted with situations, they are confused and don't know what to do. What use are such generals? How can we properly nurture and select them so that complete talents emerge in abundance, ready to serve in both peaceful and urgent times? Please answer this with utmost sincerity.

data.source_text: 하늘의 문(文)이 있고, 땅의 문이 있고, 사람의 문이 있는데, 인문과 천지의 문에는 같고 다른 점이 있는가? 결승(매듭)이 있기 전에도 문이 있었는가? 하도와 낙서 중에 천지인의 문이라 할 만한 것이 있는가? 당우삼대 때 군신의 말씀, 스승과 제자의 문답, 거리와 시골의 말들이 모두 경적에 실려 문이 되었는데, 후세의 순자, 동중서, 양웅, 왕충은 문을 지으려 했으나 육경과 비교될 수 없었으니 왜인가? 문장은 시대와 함께 오르내리는데, 송원이 한당만 못하고 한당이 삼대만 못한 것은 무엇 때문인가? 한유는 팔대의 쇠퇴를 일으켰고, 구양수는 인의예악의 설을 저술했는데, 후세 사람들은 정말 모두 고문을 지을 수 없는 것인가? 염락관민 제자들이 발언하여 문을 지으니 육경을 표리했는데, 그들의 문은 무엇을 근본으로 삼았는가? 그 자세한 것을 들을 수 있는가? 그대는 평소 이를 강론하였으니, 정성을 다해 대답해 주기 바라오.
data.target_text: There are patterns of Heaven, patterns of Earth, and patterns of Humans. Are there similarities and differences between human patterns and those of Heaven and Earth? Were there patterns before the invention of knotted cords? Are there patterns of Heaven, Earth, and Humans to be found in the River Chart and Luo Writing? During the times of Tang, Yu, and the Three Dynasties, the words between rulers and ministers, the dialogues between teachers and students, and even the common speech of streets and villages were all recorded in classics and became literature. Why couldn't later writers like Xun, Dong, Yang, and Wang compare to the Six Classics, despite their literary intentions? Literature rises and falls with the times - Song and Yuan did not match Han and Tang, and Han and Tang did not match the Three Dynasties - what are the reasons for this decline? Han Yu revived literature from the decline of eight dynasties, and Ouyang Xiu wrote about benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and music. Is it truly impossible for later generations to write ancient prose? When the masters of Lian, Luo, and Guan schools expressed themselves in writing, they embodied the Six Classics - what were their literary origins? May we hear the details? You, sir, are well-versed in these matters; please respond with careful consideration to each point.

data.target_text: Question: The Doctrine of the Mean states "Without effort they hit the mark, without thinking they apprehend, these are the sages." However, Shun's [diligence], Yu's devotion to duty, King Wen's not taking rest even while eating, cannot be said to be without effort. The Duke of Zhou's contemplation of the three kings, and Confucius's thinking throughout the night cannot be said to be without thought. Then, despite the sageness of Shun, Yu, King Wen, Duke of Zhou, and Confucius, had they not yet reached the realm of effortlessness and thoughtlessness?

data.target_text: Question: The Doctrine of the Mean states "Sincerity is the Way of Heaven, and to be sincere is the Way of Man." If sincerity is one, why distinguish between Heaven's Way and Man's Way? Are Heaven and Man divided into two? From sincerity comes enlightenment - this is Heaven's Way; from enlightenment comes sincerity - this is Man's Way. Man's Way should indeed proceed from sincerity to enlightenment, but as for Heaven's Way, why should it need sincerity to achieve enlightenment?

data.target_text: Mencius said, "When I first met the king, after retiring I had the intention to leave. My long stay in Qi was not my wish." He also said, "It was not my wish," and added: "After staying three nights, I left during the day. In my heart, I still felt this was too hasty. If the king were to change, I would surely return." When he first met the king, he already had the intention to leave, yet when leaving Qi, he felt three nights was too hasty and hoped to return - why was this so?

data.target_text: The Master said, "A young person should practice filial piety at home and respectfulness abroad, should be careful and trustworthy, should love all people generally and keep close to those who are virtuous. If they still have energy left after doing all this, they should use it to study literature." The Master taught four things: culture, conduct, loyalty, and faithfulness. When the sage taught people the way of learning, in one case he emphasized moral conduct first, and in another case he emphasized literature first. Why is there this difference in the order of priority? Or did each have its own specific purpose?

data.target_text: Mencius said, "Bo Yi was the pure one among sages, Yi Yin was the responsible one among sages, Liuxia Hui was the harmonious one among sages, and Confucius was the timely one among sages." Being called timely means he embodied the strengths of the three sages, as is evident. Yet the Master wished to dwell among the Nine Barbarian tribes and traveled around the world, never staying in one place for three years. Seeking to gather wealth and beating drums to celebrate achievements - does this not contradict the ways of purity, responsibility, and harmony? I wish to hear your precise arguments on this matter.

data.target_text: The Master said: "When an uncouth fellow asked me a question, my mind was completely blank. I pressed him on both ends until I was exhausted." He also said: "If one is not eager, I do not instruct. If one is not struggling to express oneself, I do not enlighten. If I hold up one corner and the person cannot come back with the other three corners, I do not repeat the lesson." In the way the sage teaches people, there should be no discrimination, yet with the blank-minded he exhausts himself pressing both ends, and with the eager and struggling he shows one corner and does not repeat - why is this so?

data.target_text: "The Master said, 'The brave are without fear.' He also said, 'One must feel fear when facing a situation.' data.target_text: Question: Mencius said: "Bo Yi was the sage of purity, Yi Yin was the sage of responsibility, Liuxia Hui was the sage of harmony, and Confucius was the sage of timeliness." Confucius said: "I never tire of learning." Now, a sage is one who achieves greatness and transforms others, one who follows the middle way naturally without deliberation or effort. If Bo Yi had not fully achieved responsibility and harmony, Yi Yin had not fully achieved purity and harmony, and Liuxia Hui had not fully achieved purity and responsibility, why were they all called sages? And if Confucius had achieved complete perfection, why did he never tire of learning?

data.target_text: Question. A dangerous situation is one where someone secures their position. Chaos is where order exists. In ancient times of great prosperity, long-term stability and peace were beyond what later generations could achieve. Why has there never been a case of achieving stability from danger or order from chaos? No era was more dangerous than the times of Jie and Zhou, none more chaotic than the time of You, yet they ended in destruction and overthrow. Why could they not secure their positions and establish order? Tang was imprisoned at Xia Tower when the dark bird's destiny began. King Wen was confined in Youli when the mandate of the Cang clan was renewed. If these sages Tang and Wen had not encountered danger and chaos, could they have secured their positions and established order? Duke Wen of Jin endured hardships before finally achieving the covenant at Jiantu. Gou Jian of Yue endured the humiliation of servitude before ultimately defeating Wu. These could be considered cases of achieving stability from danger and order from chaos. Emperor Dezong of Tang fled to Fengtian but could not prevent the disaster of regional military governors. Liu Bei of Han struggled in Ba-Shu but ultimately failed to restore his dynasty. Though these two rulers differed in merit, why did they both fail to achieve stability from danger and order from chaos? When Jin Yuan inherited the base at Jiankang, the danger was extreme, yet he could not restore a century of decline. When Song Gao established his state at Lin'an, the chaos was at its peak, yet he only achieved partial stability in one corner - why was this? During the Six Dynasties and Five Dynasties periods, weapons clashed daily and usurpations continued. No time was more dangerous and chaotic. Could anyone then be said to have secured their position and established order? Generally, hardship produces sages and difficulty strengthens nations. Looking at past examples and historical tracks, dangers emerged repeatedly and chaos was common. Most remained in danger, with few achieving stability from it. Most remained in chaos, with difficulty achieving order from it. Whether these continuous disasters and overwhelming calamities were due to heaven's mandate or human error, let us examine today's situation. With starvation widespread and people destitute, stores empty and resources exhausted, the nation's situation can be called dangerous. With bandits rising and alarms frequent, people's hearts not virtuous and customs degraded, the country can be called chaotic. This is a great opportunity for reform and change. If we wish to transform danger into stability and chaos into order, continuing the mandate and bringing lasting peace to the nation, what is the way? Students who witness these difficult times must have something to say about this. I wish to hear your views.

data.source_text: 난세의 극에 이르면 자연히 다스릴 길이 있으니, 옛 선비들이 음이 극성하면 양이 생긴다는 비유를 든 것과 같다. 그렇다면 난세가 반드시 치세로 바뀌는 것이 음양의 순환처럼 틀림없는 것인가? 이전 시대의 일을 천리로 살펴보면 같지 않은 점이 있다. 하나라 걸왕이 어리석었을 때 성탕이 일어났고, 상나라 주왕이 포악할 때 무왕이 대신했으며, 오계가 혼란스러워 백성이 도탄에 빠졌을 때 조송이 관용으로 구제했고, 원나라가 천하를 어지럽혔을 때 명나라가 신무로써 이를 씻어냈다. 이는 인사가 천리와 부합한 것인가? 주나라가 동쪽으로 천도하고 제후국이 분열되어 결국 폭군 진시황에게 귀속되었고, 환제와 영제 때 조조와 사마씨가 이어받아 남북조의 분열로 이어졌으며, 천자가 다스림을 잃어 끝내 평정하지 못하고 주전충의 반역과 정강의 치욕이 있었으나 남쪽 피난을 면치 못하고 마침내 쿠빌라이에게 병합되었다. 이는 인사가 천리를 어긴 것인가? 혹은 운수와 관련되어 인사로는 어쩔 수 없었던 것인가? 대저 난세가 다스려질 수 있음은 음에 양이 있는 것과 같아서, 진실로 마땅히 해야 할 인사를 다하여 천리의 소장과 같이 하면 어찌 끝없는 난세만 있고 치세가 없겠는가? 그러나 이전 시대의 인사가 천리를 어긴 것이 저와 같았으니, 오늘날에 이르러 중화가 오랫동안 전복됨이 이와 같다. 이는 실로 뜻있는 선비들이 깊이 탄식하고 영원히 아파하는 바이다. 우리나라는 변방에 있어 비록 앞서 말한 바를 갑자기 논하기는 어려우나, 만약 정사를 닦아 보좌하는 도리를 체득한다면 동주처럼 될 수 있어 한 번의 치세를 이룰 수 있을 것이니, 어찌 음만 있고 양이 없는 지경에 이르겠는가? 어떻게 하면 이를 이룰 수 있을지 모르겠다. 제생들이 깊은 음의 절기에 주나라를 그리워하는 마음을 품고 있으니, 그 축적한 바를 각자 모두 진술하면 주사가 채택하여 위에 아뢸 것이다.
data.target_text:
When chaos reaches its peak, there naturally exists a way to restore order. Ancient scholars compared this to how yang emerges when yin reaches its fullness. If so, shouldn't disorder inevitably lead to order, just as yin and yang circulate?

Looking at historical events in light of heaven's principles, there are both similarities and differences. When Xia Jie was corrupt, Tang rose; when Shang Xin was cruel, King Wu replaced him; when the Five Dynasties were in turmoil and people suffered, the Song Dynasty brought benevolent relief; when the Yuan Dynasty disturbed the realm with barbarism, the Ming Dynasty cleansed it with divine might. These events aligned with heaven's principles.

However, when the Eastern Zhou declined and states split, it led to Qin's tyranny. After Huan and Ling's decline, Cao and Ma succeeded but led to Southern divisions. When heaven's control was lost, chaos couldn't be resolved, leading to Zhu Quanzhong's rebellion. The Jingkang disaster was tragic, yet they couldn't recover and eventually succumbed to Kublai Khan's unification. Did these events deviate from heaven's principles? Or were they predetermined by fate beyond human control?

Generally, chaos can be governed like yin contains yang. If one fulfills human responsibility like heaven's natural cycles, how can disorder persist without order? Yet unlike past events that deviated from heaven's principles, today China has long suffered upheaval, causing deep sorrow among righteous people.

Though our nation lies in the outer territories and cannot readily address these matters, if we reform governance following the principles of assistance and support, we might achieve order like the Eastern Zhou and avoid becoming just yin without yang. How can we accomplish this? Students, in this darkest season, holding thoughts of the capital, present your accumulated wisdom for the authorities to select and report.

data.target_text: Question: The Analects say "The Master's words about human nature and the Way of Heaven could not be heard," yet Mencius said "Know human nature and you know Heaven" and "Sincerity is the Way of Heaven," while Zisi said "What Heaven ordains is called nature" and "From sincerity to enlightenment is called nature." Why did Mencius and Zisi speak so freely about human nature and the Way of Heaven when these were subjects the Master would not discuss?

data.target_text: Question: When Yan Yuan asked about benevolence, Confucius said "To overcome oneself and return to propriety is benevolence." However, when speaking of Guan Zhong, he said "If even Guan Zhong knows propriety, who doesn't know propriety?" and also said "How benevolent he is, how benevolent he is!" Having criticized his lack of propriety yet praising his benevolence, this seems to contradict the answer given to Yan Yuan. Why is this so?

data.target_text: Question: Mencius said "People's trouble lies in wanting to be teachers of others," but also said "To get talented people from all over the world and educate them is also a joy." Confucius said "Living among benevolent people is beautiful; how can one be wise if they choose not to live among the benevolent?" but also wished to live among the Nine Yi tribes, saying "If a noble person lives there, how can it be considered crude?" Why are these sayings of the sages seemingly contradictory?

data.target_text: Question: Zengdian said, "In late spring, when spring clothes are ready, I would like to go with five or six adults wearing caps and six or seven youngsters to bathe in the Yi River, enjoy the breeze at the Rain Dance altar, and return home singing." The Master sighed with approval and said, "I agree with Dian. In this, he flows as one with heaven, earth, and all things, each finding their perfect place. Can this not be understood?" However, he only speaks of late spring and not of the other seasons - summer, autumn, and winter. Is there no such pleasure in these seasons? I wish to discuss this with you scholars.
